(c) Similar remarks apply to roof where the actual roof covering is con cealed by planking. 3. With these exceptions the plans and sections show practically every detail and will allow of whatever it may be considered necessary to show, being drawn afresh. Mistakes in drawing the plans sent are numerous, but the dimensions given are correct and should be followed. 4. With regard to the nature of occupation of the rooms in the stables, it may be remarked that these are not at present in use as such. Suitable titles have been given to the various rooms except in the case of one small room which may be intended as an extra forage room. 5. The plans sent with your letter under reply are returned. Except that the design for iron railing in the proposed balcony is that actually adopted in the balcony on the north side of the main building the six plans received have no reference to actual work as carried out. 6. With reference to your letter No. KH9-E.B., dated 7th March 1906, asking ( me to arrange, if possible, lor preparation of plans of the Basrah Consulate buildings, I have the honour to say that I do not, at present, see any prospect of my being able to get the plans made for some time to come. 2. Up to the present moment, I have been fully occupied in pushing on the outdoor work of levelling the ground on the left bank of the Karun river, in regard to which I am writing a letter to you to-day. I am now arranging 4to go out into camp, north of Ahwaz, to reconnoitre suitable alignments for the road which the d’Arcy Oil Syndicate requires to be made, for conveying material up to Musjid-i-Suleman {vide telegraphic correspondence ending with foreign Secretary’s telegram No. 1400-E.A ,of 30th March 1906 to Major Cox, Political Kesident in the Persian Gulf.) 3. I understand that I am correct in supposing that these two works are of first importance for me to deal with. To go to Busrah would necessitate my being absent from Ahwaz, in a direction practically opposite to that in which the road for the Syndicate lies, for at least a month, and, perhaps, six weeks, owing to the nature of the work required at Basrah and the infrequency of the steamer service between Ahwaz and Basrah. 4. The only subordinate I have will be fully occupied with outdoor work, or the Karun irrigation scheme, to the middle of May, after which date he should at once plot the levels taken, assumins: that I am fully occupied elsewhere than at Ahwaz on the Syndicate’s road, as is likely to be the case. I could not send him down alone, but should have myself to go to Basrah, to see that the work was fully done in the first instance, as far as the circumstances of the case permit, to avoid further references later. If I see an opportunity of getting the plans made later on, I will at once proceed to Basrah, and report having done so to you, and, as soon as possible, state when the plans may he expected, but, at present, it is obviously impossible to fix a date for either the one or the other. 5. Sir, We have the honour to reply to your Political despatch No. 89, dated the 2nd September 1904, on the subject of the cost of the Basrah Consulate, and proposed arrangements for the maintenance of the Post Office there. 2. We are of opinion that all internal repairs to the Post Office portion of the building should he arranged for by His Majesty’s Consul, a direct payment being made to him on this account, and we are willing to accept his assessment of the cost debitable to Indian revenues. As regards the external repairs, the Consul will apparently have no direct concern with them, and a payment to him on this account would, we think, complicate matters unnecessarily. We consider that the best arrangement would be for the Government of India to bear a moiety of the cost of all external repairs executed by the Office of Works, the total cost of such repairs being divided, if possible, in the same proportion as the estimated capital cost of the Post Office rooms bears to the estimated capital cost of the rest of the Consulate. This contribution from Indian revenues might, if you see no objection, be made through the India Office. 3. We trust that these views will meet with the approval of His Majesty’s Government. We have the honour to be, Sir,

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the volume. The subject 370 (Turkish Arabia: Basra Consulate expenditure) consists of one volume.

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at the first folio with 1 and terminates at the last folio with 127; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. The foliation sequence does not include the front and back covers, nor does it include the two leading and ending flyleaves.

mods.abstract: The main contents of the volume are exchanges of letters about government expenditure on building maintenance and repairs to the British Consulate and Post Office at Basrah [Basra] in what is referred to as Turkish Arabia. The correspondence is mainly between British officials at the Foreign Office, India Office, Treasury and Office of Works in London and Government of India officials at the Foreign Department in Calcutta.
